issue.title: Enable liboqs nist-branch with OpenSSL 1.1.1
issue.body: Currently, the OQS-OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable branch only supports liboqs's master. Enable using the nist-branch.

comment.body: See PR #47 adding OQS_DEFAULT and nsit-branch KEMs.

issue.title: Autoconf's config.h shouldn't be a public header exported by liboqs master
issue.body:
On liboqs master branch, autoconf generates a config.h file which contains macros based on the results of all of the ./configure tests, as well as all of the options that were passed to ./configure, such as which algorithms to enable and where OpenSSL is.

This config.h should not be exported as a public header from liboqs, because the various macros that were set by ./configure might conflict with those present in a relying application.  (I ran into this bug when trying to build our OpenSSL 1.1.1 against our liboqs master (with OpenSSL enabled) on macOS; in particular the OPENSSLDIR macro ends up conflicting and causing build failures.)

We use config.h in two ways:

1. To export various configuration information about liboqs, such as what version of liboqs it is and which KEMs/SIGs were enabled.
2. Within liboqs to know if various build options are available, such as USE_AES_NI.

We should separate these two functionalities.  One file should contain the exported liboqs configuration options and this should be part of the installed public headers.  The other file should contain the raw output from ./configure, and not be installed as part of the public headers.

My solution is to create a distinct oqsconfig.h which contains just the liboqs configuration macros, which is part of the exported headers.  On nist-branch, this will be generated by make.  On master branch, this will be generated by grepping ./configure's config.h for all lines with `OQS_` in them.

Various calling files have to change in order to work correctly with this, including:

- calling applications should only `#include <oqs/oqs.h>` which then includes the relevant oqsconfig.h file
- code within liboqs that needs to know about macros detected by ./configure has to explicitly `#include "../../config.h"` (for however many levels of `..` it takes to refer to the root of the liboqs directory tree).

comment.body: I can't test the nist-branch + OpenSSL 1.1.1 anymore: running the programs always fail saying that liboqs.so can't be found, even if I specified the "no-shared" configure option. It was failing on my dev box, and I also get the same thing on a clean VM. I don't think I introduced something in this PR that would affect that. Can someone else repro? @dstebila ? @smashra ?

issue.title: Added more OQS KEM and documented nist-branch.
issue.body:
*NOT READY FOR MERGE*: need to test all new schemes.

Added OQS default kem and the nist-supported kem. Also documented how to build OpenSSL with OQS's nist-branch.

comment.body:
The problem is that running OpenSSL 1.1.1 `./Configure no-shared` tells OpenSSL's build system not to build shared versions of libcrypto and libssl, but still allows us to make use of shared libraries for components it depends on, including liboqs.  If liboqs.so is present in /path/to/openssl/oqs, then OpenSSL will build against the liboqs.so shared library, even if you were not building an OpenSSL shared library.

The README.md on OQS-OpenSSL\_1]\_1\_1-stable build instructions for liboqs master disable building liboqs.so with the option `--enable-shared=no`.  We currently don't have instructions for nist-branch (we need to add them).  There's no option to tell the basic Makefile in nist-branch to not build a shared library, so what you need to do is delete liboqs.so from /path/to/openssl/oqs/lib after you've done the nist-branch `make install PREFIX-/path/to/openssl/oqs`.

issue.title: Added more OQS KEM and documented nist-branch.

Added OQS default kem and the nist-supported kem. Also documented how to build OpenSSL with OQS's nist-branch.

comment.body: You can build the shared version and it will work, you just have to make sure that libssl and libcrypto are in a place where the runtime linker will find them.  Since we recommend that people don't make install our OpenSSL into the system default /usr directory, they'd have to correctly specify the LD\_LIBRARY\_PATH.  I thought it would be simpler for the (basic) instructions to just avoid shared libraries.

issue.title: Added more OQS KEM and documented nist-branch.
issue.body:
*NOT READY FOR MERGE*: need to test all new schemes.

Added OQS default kem and the nist-supported kem. Also documented how to build OpenSSL with OQS's nist-branch.

comment.body:
@christianpaquin 

~~~bash
cd liboqs-nist
make -j
make install PREFIX=/path/to/openssl/oqs
cd ../openssl
rm oqs/lib/liboqs.so
./Configure no-shared linux-x86_64-cc
make -j
~~~
